Dmitry Ovcharov |commander1_label = Current commander |native_name = {{lang-ru|31-я отдельная гвардейская десантно-штурмовая ордена Кутузова II степени бригада}} }} The '''31st Separate Guards Order of Kutuzov 2nd class Air Assault Brigade''' is an airborne [[infantry]] [[brigade]] of the [[Russian Airborne Troops]], based in [[Ulyanovsk]]. The brigade was formed in 1998 from the [[104th Guards Airborne Division]]. The brigade fought in the [[Second Chechen War]] and the [[Russo-Georgian War]]. During the [[2014 Crimean crisis|Crimean crisis 2014]] elements of the brigade were located in the [[Crimean peninsula]]. In August 2014 brigade's units participated in the [[War in Donbas]].{{Cite journal|url=https://rusi.org/sites/default/files/201503_bp_russian_forces_in_ukraine.pdf|title=RUSI Briefing Paper: Russian Forces in Ukraine|last=Sutyagin|first=Igor|date=March 2015|journal=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=6 April 2016|publisher=[[Royal United Services Institute]]|issue=|volume=|via=|page=2}} ==History== The brigade was created as a result of the disbandment of the [[104th Guards Airborne Division]] in 1998 at Ulyanovsk. Between 1999 and 2001, the brigade fought in the [[Second Chechen War]]. For their actions during the war, Senior lieutenants [[Grigory Galkin]] and [[Roman Igoshin]] were awarded the title [[Hero of the Russian Federation]] (Igoshin posthumously).{{Cite web|title = 31-я отдельная гвардейская десантно-штурмовая Ордена Кутузова 2-й степени бригада : Министерство обороны Российской Федерации|url = http://structure.mil.ru/structure/forces/airborne/structure/details.htm?id=11272@egOrganization|website = structure.mil.ru|accessdate = 2015-12-18|language = Russian|trans-title = 31st Separate Guards Airborne Brigade Order of Kutuzov 2nd class: Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation}} Since 2005, the brigade has used a contract manning system. On 1 December 2006, it was redesignated as an air assault brigade. A battalion tactical group of the brigade fought in the [[Russo-Georgian War]] in 2008.{{Cite web|title = Прощай, оружие|url = http://old.redstar.ru/2008/08/27_08/2_03.html|website = old.redstar.ru|accessdate = 2015-12-18|language = Russian|trans-title = A farewell to Arms}} A monument to Army General [[Vasily Margelov]] is located at the brigade's base in Ulyanovsk. In April 2010, VDV commander [[Vladimir Shamanov]] visited the brigade and viewed its battalion tactical exercises. {{Cite web|url=http://desantura.ru/news/421/|title=Командующий ВДВ инспектирует войска|website=desantura.ru|language=Russian|trans-title=VDV Comamnder inspects troops|access-date=2016-03-03}} The brigade was part of the [[Collective Rapid Reaction Force]] as of 2013.{{Cite news|title = CSTO Moves Into The Information Age|url = http://www.rferl.org/content/commentary_csto_moves_into_information_age/24317363.html|newspaper = RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|date = 2011-09-04|access-date = 2016-02-07|language = English|first = Roger|last = McDermott}} In February 2014, elements of the brigade were sent to Crimea.{{Cite web|url = http://ipc-dzhankoy.org/center_news/13738.html|title = В Джанкое находятся войска Чеченской Республики|date = 5 March 2014|access-date = 10 March 2014|website = IPC Dzhankoy|publisher = |last = |first = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140310050018/http://ipc-dzhankoy.org/center_news/13738.html|archive-date = 10 March 2014|language = Russian|trans-title = In Dzhankoy are forces of the Chechen Republic}} Brigade troops assaulted the building of [[State Council of Crimea|Crimean Parliament]], wearing Ukrainian [[Berkut (special police force)|"Berkut" police]] uniforms and insignia.{{Cite news|url=https://informnapalm.org/en/how-ukrainian-berkut-officer-from-russian-ulyanovsk-assaulted-crimean-parliament-back-in-2014/|title=How ‘Ukrainian Berkut Officer’ from Russian Ulyanovsk Assaulted Crimean Parliament Back in 2014|date=2015-07-09|newspaper=InformNapalm.org (English)|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-31}} In August 2014 the brigade's units fought in the [[Battle of Ilovaisk]]. On 26 August a column of mixed [[8th Guards Mountain Motor Rifle Brigade|8th Mountain Brigade]] and 31st Air Assault Brigade units was ambushed by a Ukrainian anti-tank artillery squad of the [[51st Guards Mechanized Brigade (Ukraine)|51st Mechanized Brigade]] near Mnohopillya village.{{Cite news|url=http://censor.net.ua/resonance/364226/kapitan_kotoryyi_izmenil_hod_voyiny|title=КАПИТАН, КОТОРЫЙ ИЗМЕНИЛ ХОД ВОЙНЫ|last=|first=|date=|work=Censor.net|newspaper=|language=ru-RU|trans-title=The captain who changed the course of the war|access-date=31 October 2016|via=}} Two soldiers of 31st Brigade were captured: Ruslan Akhmetov and Arseniy Ilmitov.{{Cite news|url=https://informnapalm.org/en/embarrassment-russia-soldiers-captured-ukraine/|title=Embarrassment for Russia With Their Soldiers Being Captured in Ukraine. - InformNapalm.org (English)|date=2014-12-18|newspaper=InformNapalm.org (English)|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-31}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.matthewaid.com/post/102192872011/most-russian-soldiers-killed-in-the-wat-in-the|title=Most Russian Soldiers Killed in the Wat in the Ukraine Came From 5 Elite Airborne Units, Report|website=Matthew Aid|access-date=2016-10-31}}{{Citation|last=Igor Panko|title=Ruslan Akhmetov and Arseniy Ilmitov interrogation (2014/08/28)|date=2014-08-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B4ISqFswDsw|accessdate=2016-10-31}} During a rescue attempt, another 31st Brigade unit was ambushed. Nikolai Kozlov, a paratrooper who participated in the [[State Council of Crimea|Crimean Parliament]] building takeover in February, lost his leg in the ambush.{{Cite news|url=https://www.novayagazeta.ru/articles/2014/09/08/61043-bilet-v-odin-konets|title=Билет в один конец|newspaper=Новая газета - Novayagazeta.ru|language=ru-RU|access-date=2016-10-31}} During the Ukrainian forces' withdrawal from Ilovaisk on August 29th, [[Donbas Battalion]] fighters were able to capture two soldiers of the 31st Air Assault Brigade near [[Chervonosilske]] village: Nikita Terskikh and Eugen Sardaryan, as well as some soldiers of [[6th Tank Brigade (Russia)|6th Tank Brigade]].{{Cite news|url=https://informnapalm.org/7194-ynternet-polzovately-ydentyfytsyrovaly-plennyh-rossyjskyh-soldat-pod-ylovajskom/|title=Интернет-пользователи идентифицировали пленных российских солдат под Иловайском - Inform Napalm|date=2015-03-22|newspaper=Inform Napalm|language=ru-RU|access-date=2016-10-31}} On 4 June 2015, the Russian Ministry of Defence announced that the 104th Guards Airborne Division would be reformed from the brigade.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/armiya-i-opk/2018476|title=Источник в Генштабе: Ульяновскую бригаду ВДВ преобразуют в дивизию|last=|first=|date=4 June 2015|work=[[Russian News Agency "TASS"|TASS]]|language=Russian|trans-title=General Staff source: Ulyanovsk Airborne Brigade to be converted to division|access-date=3 March 2016|via=}} In March 2016, the brigade temporarily moved from its base at Ulyanovsk to [[Orenburg]] in snap readiness drills.{{Cite web|url=http://tass.ru/en/defense/864507|title=Russia’s Ulyanovsk airborne formation redeployed to Orenburg range for drills|website=TASS|access-date=2016-04-06}} == Commanders == * Major General [[Vadim Orlov]] (1998-2000) * Colonel Sergey Yevgenyevich Kapustin (2000-2002) * Colonel Nikolai Sergeyevich Nikulnikov (2002-2005) * Colonel [[Vladimir Anatolyevich Kochetkov]] (2005-2007) * Colonel [[Dmitry Glushchenkov|Dmitry Vasilyevich Glushchenkov]] (2010-2012) * Colonel [[Gennady Anashkin|Gennady Vladimirovich Anashkin]] (2012-2014) * Colonel Dmitry Ovcharov (2014-present) ==Composition== Brigade units: *2 Air Assault Battalions *Airborne Battalion *Artillery Battalion *Military Transport Aviation Squadron *Support units == Gallery == 31 ODShBr VSRF.png|Brigade sleeve patch (since 2006) Russian 31st Airborne Brigade patch.svg|Brigade sleeve patch (till 2006) ==References== {{Russian Airborne Troops}} [[Category:Airborne infantry brigades of Russia]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1998]]
